question: You are a coding expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be sure to ensure that the generated code is executable for demonstration. Create a racing game with a first-person driver's perspective, allowing for left and right turns, acceleration and deceleration based on the track. The track should resemble a realistic three-dimensional racing circuit.

checklist.title: Is the first-person 3D racing view accurately implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code correctly implements a first-person perspective camera system using WebGL/Three.js or Canvas 3D, including proper field of view (FOV 60-90°), camera positioning inside the cockpit, and realistic depth perception. The view should include dashboard elements and steering wheel. Score 0 if only 2D top-down view is provided, 5 if basic 3D view without cockpit details, and 10 if full immersive first-person racing experience with proper perspective projection.

checklist.title: Are the vehicle physics and control mechanics realistic?
checklist.description: Check whether the implementation includes proper physics simulation for acceleration, deceleration, steering dynamics, and momentum conservation. Vehicle should have inertia, drift mechanics, speed-dependent turning radius, and realistic braking distance. Keyboard/gamepad controls should be responsive with proper input mapping (WASD/Arrow keys for steering, acceleration/braking). Deduct 5 points if physics feel arcade-like without momentum, 3 points if steering lacks progressive response. Full score requires realistic vehicle dynamics.

checklist.title: Is the 3D racing track properly designed and rendered?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the track features realistic 3D geometry with proper banking, elevation changes, curves of varying difficulty, and track boundaries. Track should include visual elements like barriers, grass/gravel run-off areas, start/finish line, and lap markers. Texture mapping and lighting should create depth and realism. Deduct 5 points if track is flat without elevation, 3 points if missing proper track boundaries or visual landmarks. Full score requires professional circuit-like design.

checklist.title: Is the complete racing game loop implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes essential racing features: lap counting system, timing/speed display, race start countdown, finish line detection, and basic HUD (speedometer, lap counter, position). Should handle race completion, lap records, and restart functionality. Deduct 5 points if lap detection is inaccurate, 3 points if missing essential HUD elements, 2 points if no timing system. Give 10 points if all core racing mechanics are properly implemented with accurate tracking.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as collision detection edge cases, frame rate drops, browser compatibility issues, memory leaks in 3D rendering, invalid input states) and provide appropriate fallbacks or error handling. Code should gracefully handle WebGL context loss and provide meaningful error messages. Give 10 points for comprehensive error handling, 5 points for basic exception management, and 0 points if no error handling is implemented.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that enhance the racing experience?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes engaging features that elevate the gameplay (e.g., 1. Realistic engine sound effects with Doppler effect 2. Dynamic weather/lighting conditions 3. Multiple camera angles 4. Ghost car for lap comparison 5. Particle effects for tire smoke/sparks). Add 3 points for each well-implemented innovative feature that adds value to the racing experience (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant rendering pipelines or duplicate 3D model loading 2. Unnecessary non-racing features (e.g., built-in chat system, unrelated mini-games) 3. Performance-heavy visual effects that don't enhance racing (e.g., excessive particle systems, overly complex shaders). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if core racing performance is significantly impacted by bloated features.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular architecture separating rendering engine, physics simulation, input handling, and game state management. Check for proper asset loading optimization, frame rate management (targeting 60fps), and memory usage patterns. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution or poor separation of concerns; deduct 5 points if code duplication rate exceeds 30% or lacks consistent coding patterns; deduct 5 points if no performance optimization considerations for 3D rendering. Full score requires clean, maintainable architecture.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional racing game standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the visual design follows modern racing game UI principles: 1) High contrast HUD elements clearly visible against track background 2) Realistic color palette with appropriate track surface textures 3) Professional typography for racing data (lap times, speed) with adequate sizing (≥16px for critical info). Deduct 3 points for each cluttered HUD element, 5 points for poor contrast affecting readability, and 5 points for unrealistic or distracting visual styling that breaks immersion.

checklist.title: Is the racing performance smooth and responsive?
checklist.description: Judge whether the game performance meets racing standards: 1) Consistent frame rate ≥30fps (preferably 60fps) during gameplay 2) Input lag ≤50ms for steering responsiveness 3) Smooth camera movement without stuttering during high-speed sections 4) Proper LOD (Level of Detail) management for distant track elements. Deduct 5 points for each noticeable frame drop during normal racing, 3 points for input delay affecting control precision, and 5 points for camera jitter or motion sickness-inducing movement.
